div.l: And atte Mille þe sakke he down̄ leide
Aleyn spak first al haile Symond he seide
Howe fares þi faire dought̉er and þi wife
Aleyn welcome qduod Symond be my life
A Iohn how now what do ye her͗e
Bi god qduod Iohn nede hath no per͗e
Hīm bihoueth ʆserue hīm self þat hath no swayne
Or ellez he is a fole as clerkes sayne
Our͗e manciple I hope wol be/dedebededebe dede
So werkes ay þe wongꝭes of his hede
And ther͗e for I is cōmmyn̄ and eke Aleyn̄
To grinde our͗e corne and to cari it home a gayn̄
I prai yow spede vs hens what ye may
It shal be done qduod Symkyn̄ bi my fay
What wol ye do whil it is in honde
Bi god bi þe hoper will I stonde
Qduod Iohn and se how þe corn̄ goth in
Yit saw I neuer bi my fader kyn̄
How þat þe hopper wagges two and fro
Aleyn answhered Iohn wilt þou so
Þen wil I be byneth be my corn̄
And se howe þe mele falleth down̄
Into þe þrough þat shal be my disporte
For Iohn in faith I may be of your͗e sorte
I am as euell a myller as be ye
Þis myller͗e smyleth at þeir͗e nycete
And þought al þis is done but for a wile
Þei wene þat no man may þeim begile
But be my thrift yit shal I bler͗e her͗e ey
For al þe sleght of þeir͗e philosophy
The more queynte crekes þat þey make
Þe mor͗e wol I stele whan I take
In stede of flour͗e I woll geue þeym brenne
Þe grettest clerkes beth not þe wisest menne
As whilom þe wolf spak to þe mar͗e
Of al þeir͗e arte I counte not a tar͗e
Oute atte dore he goeth ful priuely
And whan he sagh his tyme softly
He loked vp and down̄ til he hath founde
Þe clerkes horse ther͗e as he was bounde
Bi hinde þe myll vndr͗e a lefesell
And to þe horse he goth faire and well
He striped of þe bridell and þat a none
